column3: Long Island City, New York, NY
column6: This place is amazing. My husband and I went here Friday night. We ordered 4 dishes, everything was so good. Duck Liver, blown my mind, one of the best I have ever tried in NYC. Beef Tenderlion, highly recommended. Cheese Soufflé is also recommended, I have never tried a soufflé like this. Will definitely come back.

Excellent experience. Service was top notch. Food was delicious and perfect prepared. We went for brunch and had a bottle of Austrian Riesling recommended by their Somm. She was so lovely and killed with every rec. finished with an Austrian dessert wine. We highly recommend this establishment. Executive chef was preset and making sure the whole restaurant was perfect. Only negative was I wish my chair was more comfortable. Great comfortable ambiance with highly executed comfort food. By the way, everything bread related was phenomenal.

Had a great brunch here. Ordered the duck parfait which was delicious. The smoked salmon and bagel was really good and not your typical platter with a really good bagel texture, flavorful fluffy cream cheese, and of course high quality salmon. Also got the pork schnitzel which was wonderful - very thin piece of breaded pork with lingonberry sauce and some cucumbers.

Excellent restaurant ! Initially I was intimidated by the menu and I wasn't sure if I would like it but everything was so good! We started with gougeres which was cheesy and delicious. I didn't love the sauce that went with it (friend did). Then we had the cheese soufflé (so soft!) and the beets (my least favorite but still good). I had the salmon en croute which was really excellent. My friends had the risotto and fennel tagliatelle both also really good. We ended with creme brulee and cheesecake excellent. Our server was so nice and helpful. Ambiance was nice as well - I just didn't love that you have to walk through a hotel to go to the bathroom and had a totally different feel. Would highly recommend

The entrance of Koloman is a little discrete, but when you walk in, you're greeted by a very stately, sophisticated interior. The service was impeccable - right away, they checked in our coats and took us to our table. The ambiance is slightly ruined by the crowd near the bar area, which didn't match the otherwise chic vibe of the restaurant, and the tables placed really close together. The standout here is definitely the salmon en croute - the perfectly crispy and buttery crust goes so well with the tender salmon and tangy beetroot sauce. The cheese soufflé and the gougeres (mainly bread and cheese with red wine shallots) were also noteworthy, practically melting in your mouth. I was disappointed, however, by the snapper crudo. I wasn't getting much flavor or texture in the dish. And of course, this place is extremely pricey, so the food didn't wow me the way I expected it to. Overall, though, I would recommend checking out this spot to anybody looking for a delicious salmon dish.
beautiful & impressive space, excellently prepared & exciting food, top notch service. don't hesitate to book a res brunch or dinner.

column3: Upper East Side, New York, NY

column6: Chef Markus Glocker has long been a New York culinary star since his days at Batard. Now he brings his considerable culinary talents to Koloman which is in the old Breslin space in the Ace Hotel in Nomad. Named after the Austrian artist Koloman Moser, the food is either French with an Austrian accent or Austrian with French classic techniques. Either way you want to describe it, the food is great. Chef Glocker's  schnitzel is as fabulous as ever. The Duck Liver Parfait is sublime and the Cheese Soufflé is wonderful. Cocktails are great as well.

On the second visit, a much-improved Koloman.  The standouts were the fluke, the chicken -- like a bresse chicken only with two beautiful pieces of foie gras on top, both souffle (for the middle course and desert) and the Oysters. The bread course with butter was fresh and butter flavorful. Cocktails original and interesting, particularly the Bitter Truth, Edelweiss and Karo.   Service was excellent.  Would go back in a minute.

Made an unplanned stop here on a Thursday night and was highly impressed! We just sat at the bar a got one round of drinks. The cocktails were very unique and tasted amazing!! Will be coming back to try the dining menu and more cocktails!

One of the best meals I've had in a while. Service was personal and excellent. The food was really delicious.  The wine and the cocktails were also great. Solid presentation of the food. Will definitely come again!!

Arrived early for 6:15 reservation. Reception very accommodating and seated me before the other diner arrived. It was suggested by our waiter that we order 3 to 4 courses each since servings were small.  Once we ordered it took a long time between courses - we asked about our order and patiently waited.  Quite a while after submitting credit cards for payment waiter returned and apologized for delay due to system not working properly.  Finally our cards were returned and when we signed our checks it was now almost 8:30. Quite a long experience due to restaurant issues.   Food was lovely, Waiter and bus staff were great AND THEN .....  THE MANAGER APPROACHED OUR TABLE AND TOLD US TO LEAVE AS HE NEEDED THE TABLE AS THERE WERE PEOPLE WAITING  -  WHAT???  Destroyed the whole experience

column3: Upper East Side, New York, NY

column6: Woo hoo!  Fun night in a nice new restaurant.  Awesome buzz at this place.  Friends assured me that the decor is authentically Austrian.  It was a bit dark, but nice.  The waitstaff were excellent and very attentive, as one would expect in a new restaurant run by big name chefs.  They have a sommelier!  An excellent one, who did not immediately push super expensive bottles of wine.  We drank an excellent bottle of gruner veltliner and I had my first Austrian Chardonnay.  The bread was excellent and hot- the poppy seed rolls were awesome.  We sampled an assortment of appetizers.  The gougeres were awesome and served as a delivery vehicle for some ethereal truffle butter.  We also tried the crudo, celery root tartare, souffle and tagliatelle.  They were all excellent.  Our table was evenly split between the salmon and the fluke.  The salmon was awesome.  The pastry crust was rich and delicious.  Our table mates were equally happy with the fluke.  Awesome restaurant experience.  One very minor complaint- they don't serve decaf coffee!
Koloman is the latest creation of chef Markus Glocker. Every element of this dining experience is an achievement in the finest anyone could hope for. Hats off to the team at Koloman
Everything is perfect in here! Love the medium rare beef tenderloin and salmon en croute!

Friendly service who gave us good recommendations. For instance, we wouldn't have known that the boeuf was prepared in 3 different ways, but we definitely appreciated the dish's variety of textures. The salmon en croute was also melt-in-your-mouth tender. I do wish we had opted for a dessert that is more of a Viennese specialty since the caramelized milk bread tasted a little lackluster compared to the savory parts of dinner, but overall, a lovely and interesting dinner.
One of the best dinners I've had in NYC. Food was so fantastic, service was great! The restaurant is really beautiful. Highly recommend!

I enjoyed but did not love Koloman, and this is not an inexpensive restaurant. We split the beets "linzer" and the Short Rib Tafelspitz Terrine. Both were very good. The beets were fairly basic, with a bit of linzer crumble strewn in, and some creme fraiche lining the plate. The terrine was a bit more interesting, and the flavors were nice. For mains, my pal got the Schnitzel (I found this a little greasy) and I had the beautiful -- and very tasty --  Salmon En Croute. The Salmon was faultless, but not thrilling. For dessert we split the soufflé with rum and lingonberries, and it was very good, but I was a little disappointed (am I being too picky) that it wasn't served in a soufflé ramekin but a shallow dish. The flavors were there, but the presentation was blah. I would be more disposed to love this place if it wasn't so pricey, but much like Frenchette (which I think is a more interesting and better restaurant) it's not a place I will visit regularly.

Came for dessert late Saturday night and had the greatest experience. It was lively but they were still able to accommodate my party of 6 and we had some of the best desserts I've ever had. The soufle, lava cake, and marzipan were SO GOOD!!! Loved! Thank you!

Fantastic little place attached to the Ace Hotel. We went for brunch, a group of 4, got a reservation ahead of time. We got seated promptly, they checked our coats (which I SO appreciate), service was excellent and the food and drinks were all delicious. Jazz was playing in the background, yet it was intimate enough for a conversation or a date. We can't wait to go back.

Best dining experience since the pandemic! At first we found the noise level and very close tables to other diners daunting but loved the great design of this special place. The restaurant is named after Moses Koloman and incorporates his design and light fixtures circa 1900 Vienna. We loved the cheese soufflé and corn scallop soup and pork rib terrine. The dessert soufflé was a great finale to our meal and was so light and perfect!  Our waiter Joe was great and Chef Marcus came to our table to say hi. It is a very special and unique evening and we can't wait to go back again!

I was very excited to try Koloman and it exceeded expectations. The service - from front of house to the servers and wine professionals - everyone was knowledgeable and friendly. The food was exceptional and inventive. The celery root tartar was a surprise hit, cheese soufflé is a must-have. Really enjoyed it and looking forward to going back.

Wow. Just an amazing experience start to finish. Fantastic service and even better food, somehow. Definitely recommend the boeuf and butternut squash soup appetizers and roast chicken for dinner but everything was amazing. Some affordable wines too, really good Austrian ones. This place is set to be one of the best french restaurants in NY already.

We came to this restaurant because it was advertised as Viennese. We loved what we saw on the website for the menu. However, when we arrived at 1 o'clock on a Saturday, it was in fact, just a normal hotel breakfast. Eggs and that type of thing there was nothing Austrian about it. So disappointing.

Delicious, heavy, perhaps overrated. We had high expectations based on NYT review. The food was lovely but definitely VERY rich. We were seated upstairs, less than amazing ambiance especially given the price of the food. Memorable meal but not sure I'd return anytime soon.

Food is good. However, there is a thing that happens of many restaurants which is nobody asks me how was the food, but they ask the white people around me. They is the daily life of being Asian in America. I really don't wanna say it is micro aggressive but it's happened so many times in this state.
Ridiculous restaurant. Food took forever wait staff was clumsy. Front of house generally didn't have a clue. If you are going to charge those prices it amounts to fraud.

This was one of the best NYC restaurants in terms of food that I have tried in recent memory.  The warm poppyseed rolls alone with were the trip.  We had the short rib terrine and snapper crudo to start.  Both were excellent and the terrine was such a delight especially compared to the same the standard boring starters at so many places.  The duck and beef as mains were both outstanding.  Service was very attentive but laid back and friendly, not stuffy.  The decor was lovely.  The only slight negative was how very expensive most the wine list was (even the wines by the glass).  We each had a cocktail to start, both of which were really well made, but passed on the wine.

The food was excellent -- expensive but where isn't? -- but the service was a bit chaotic and slow. There are tons of staff but they seemed a bit frazzled. You shouldn't have to wait for everyone to arrive before being seated and then have to wait for a drink...

The review by Pete Wells which awarded three stars to Koloman is incomplete.  A mention that the restaurant serves brunch prompted me to invite 3 guests to join me at this lauded restaurant on Sunday, Dec.11th.  My interaction with the hostess should have been a warning that this place was not ready for prime time.  She looked at my Open Table confirmation when she could not find my reservation and noted the 12:30PM time.  She was kind enough to point  out that 12:30 PM is dinner, not brunch, and I was kind enough to tell her that 12:30 PM is noon.  I should also note that Koloman had my credit card as security.  Finally crowded into a booth for four, we perused the menu and made our selections.  We opted for the simple  bacon and eggs, omelet and salads.  The scrambled eggs with bacon turned out to be a flat pancake with some bacon beneath the flattened eggs.  The other egg order received the same treatment; the bit of bacon buried beneath the eggs.  Along with the eggs, we were served a tiny portion of diced potatoes of no particular flavor  to A confusing join the no taste egg dishes.  Butter and jam were provided when requested.  The overall brunch was someone's idea of a Viennese repast, but failed on al counts.  Bacon was hard to find, meager, and hard to taste.  Eggs , adequate but tasteless, and no way scrambled in any cuisine.  The space, crowded and noisy, was hardly a 3 star experience.  Perhaps that is why Mr. wells did not explore or sample the brunch menu.  But we did and do not recommend it to anyone.
Decided to grab a very late dinner here. Really nice vibes and an amazing wait staff. The beet salad and beef tenderloin was delicious!! Thank you for such a wonderful dinner!!

Everything, from start to finish, was near-perfect; even the bread service was outstanding. Celery root tartare, short rib and tafelspitz terrine, roasted duck with oranges, lingonberry soufflé: all superlative. If there was one weak link, it was the schnitzel; very good, but ordinary compared to the fireworks of the other dishes. There were long-ish waits for the first round of drinks, and between appetizer and entree courses; but the service itself was smooth, professional and attentive. The decor is beautiful, too, but the layout of the room is such that some diners will only get a view of a blank wall. Noise level can be very loud, but if you snag a booth or corner banquette, you're buffered somewhat. All in all, a terrific meal and one which I felt justified the price tag (which, honestly, was quite reasonable given the quality -- I've paid a lot more for much less). I'm already anticipating a return visit to try the cheese soufflé and Brune Landaise chicken for two.

It's been quite sometime since I've been here, but it was good as I had always remembered! What a fantastic spot with delicious pastas and a cream of the crop wine list. OH! And those brussels sprouts are absolutely fantastic! Seriously, some of the best I've ever had! Marco our server was excellent and make the evening enjoyable. I love when a NYC fav becomes a NYC classic. So perfect!

NYC has a plethora of Italian restaurants and this place is definitely a solid. It's cozy and warm, with an even steady flow of diners. Our server was attentive and made really good recommendations. I forgot to take a snapshot of my food until the dessert. Food was absolutely delightful - we ordered the meatballs, kale salad, and various pasta dishes. There was not one bad dish. Would come back again.

Had some dinner here it was really packed but i had outdoor reservations. It's warm in the outdoor shed. My waitress was super kind with recommendations and accommodating with my entrees. The entree I wanted to order had dairy in it which i could not have the waitress told me i could get the bolognese pasta instead. Ordered the potatoes as starter. The bolognese pasta was really good actually not overwhelming. My friend ordered the salmon with broccoli but they didn't want the broccoli. When we received the dish it was jus a salmon on a plate with nothing else. I mean understandable because they delivered what we asked for. The service and vibes were amazing though!
Made reservations here for our night out in NYC and this place delivered. Unreal service and fantastic food.

Absolutely solid. Not outstanding but B+ for sure. The tagliatelle with truffle was delicious. The beet appetizer was good. The cheese board was okay and comicallyyyyy small lol. The staff were accommodating to my friends allergy and mostly friendly, but definitely trying to keep us moving along to leave. Overall it was good, but at the price it's probably not good enough for repeat visits-- especially given some of the great Italian food around!
I cannot get behind this restaurant. I find the food to be boring, flavorless and simply, mediocre. The meals are not worth the price tag and there's no vibe or ambiance. Nothing more to be said.

I was pretty disappointed with the cacio e pepe. I've had better at basic Italian places in Jersey. Tasted very buttery. The best part of our meal was probably the arancini. Wouldn't try this place again, just very average overall.
Good food, they make best pasta in New York City. Similar taste like in Italy. Authentic Italian food

So far on our 4 week trip and 6 days into our West Village trip we had our beat Meal yet! Service was excellent and the food Black pastas frutta di mare, cacio e pepe and bolognese all exceptional Crispy Brussels amazing. What a great spot and not crazy priced

Lupa is an Italian restaurant located in the Soho area. The service was good and the staff was nice. The food however was not the best. There were good dishes and some that several of our party did not like at all. Very inconsistent. With so many great restaurants in the area it's hard to justify recommending.

Mike was our server and he was amazing. The food was disappointing. We had to ask for salt and pepper because of the lack of flavor. Cacio de Pepe tasted like old pasta water and the truffle pasta didn't have any truffle flavor. I've had amazing meals here before but this last time was upsetting.

It's the first time to visit. I was craving authentic pasta so I decided to get here. Overall, good dinner but not 100% satisfaction. Liked bucatini but strozzapreti was just soso because it's too oily. Maybe it would be better if it is little bit spicy taste. Also lamb was also just okay and I need more green onion or onion. When I finish my dinner I feel like too much oil I had. Server was so friendly.

BEST FUCKING PASTA IN NEW YORK! Amazing service, kind, genuine, nice and awesome! Must go! Across Carbone but this is better! The foccacia wine and taste was fabulous. Diego, experienced server and Angelo the wine specialist was unreal. 10/10
Amazing espresso martinis, and the pastas are heaven. Traditional Italian fare, beautifully executed

This chicken dish is mind blowing! So juicy and the skin was just perfect, everyone at I went out with was envious my my choice. The staff was amazing and kind and helped us through the menu. My drink had to much ice in it. I will definitely come back to try more of there dishes.

Used to like this spot but not sure what happened. Got a plate of pasta & a side of broccoli and walked out with a $50 bill, cold soggy broccoli and pasta that lacked flavor and had a pile of water left in the bottom afterward . Go a few blocks over and get pasta somewhere else.

I so loved this place for many years, pre-covid. Sadly it is not the same, has devolved to over-priced, poor quality preparation, and unfriendly service. All is lost. And a once hard to get seat is now an empty lot. Sorry and sad, but honest review. Amatriciana was a tomatoey mess.  Kale Caesar sounds cool but un-delivers flavor and appeal.  Sadly disappointed.  Please come back to reality. Until then, I will dine elsewhere.

By far the best Italian food we have ever had.   We were visiting New York and stumbled upon this place.   Words can not describe how perfectly the food was prepared presented and tasted.   We vowed to come back any time we come to New York.  The waiter was knowledgeable and made fantastic recommendations. Also great hospitality and company. We were just sitting in the back devouring our food and our waiter brought us complimentary wine. Thank you for the great meal and memory!

I think it may have just been an off night. I had linguine with clams and everything, including the pasta was gritty. It was like the clams weren't scrubbed well enough. Everyone else in my group liked their food. My daughter had gnocchi and ate every bite. My husband had cacio e Pepe which he loved. The prosciutto antipasti was good. The service was also good.

Lupa was an exceptional dining experience from the ambience to each course served. The table focaccia was airy and oily, and the Cristini they served along side with a lemony chickpea spread was quite good. I would highly recommend getting the buratta appetizer. It was an interesting combination of flavors between the peas and the pesto. The pasta was by all means very good. The portions were reasonable and it was cooked perfectly al-dente. The pasta was reasonably sauced and the flavors were very good. I would certainly go back for a higher-end dinner!

I came in here after a long walk from midtown, and was seated with my friend by the bar. The smell was a little strong so we were moved towards the middle. Atmosphere is a bit crowded, dim lit, a rustic type place for Italian food. There's plenty of seating outside too after covid. The fried calamari and artichokes were delicious. So were the fingerling potatoes with the aioli. The burrata was fresh. Cacio e Pepe didn't disappoint, it was oozing with salty black pepper and butter. I'll try more dishes if I ever come back!
Pricey but great flavor. Glass of wine was $18 but happy with the size. Staff was friendly and helpful. Corn tortoloni was delightful.
Best Italian food in NYC. Great service, good ambiance, to-die-for bucatini amatriciana. Also an excellent spot for a cocktail.
The food was excellent.  The recommended wine was most enjoyable.   Our server was very personable and very attentive.  It was just a great experience.
Great service. The Pasta was amazing and so was the wine. Will be back to try more things on the menu.

We had a 9 pm reservation but ended up coming an hour early and grateful they seated us on a busy saturday evening!! The place was definitely bustling. We started with a shareable app of squash blossoms topped with anchovies, very good. We then each got the pasta special with chanterelles. Pasta was perfectly cooked Al dente but it was overall on the salty side (and this is coming from me who likes salt). The chanterelles were delightful, wonderful flavor and freshness. We ended sharing a cinnamon gelato and it was surprisingly light and a great finish to the heavy meal. They definitely know how to do their pastas well but recommend they cut down on the salt a bit.

Had the black spaghetti. Not the best that I've tasted but the service was good and staff very friendly and accommodating. We would have had the tasting menu but we were a party of 6 and everyone in the party apparently must order it. Perhaps we should have had it after all because the black spaghetti was just ok.

Very disappointing. I have been going to Lupa for nearly 20 years and it has always been one of my favorite Italian restaurants. Tonight, after three years and the pandemic, we returned to find that it is no longer special. It's no longer a restaurant worth traveling more than five blocks in NYC to visit. The service was indifferent. The short rib pasta - long a favorite- was under seasoned and the sauce tasted like it was cooked last minute rather than being a rich braise. The sorbetto was full of ice chunks. We had to ask repeatedly for forks when our utensils were taken away between courses. Another formerly good restaurant is now only mediocre. Just eat at your corner Italian - the welcome will be warmer and the bill more affordable. So sad.

Doesn't even deserve a star. I walked out because the restaurant has a color section in the back. One color in the front and everyone else all the way in the back by the restrooms. It was too obvious to ignore...

This place never disappoints. They stick to classic Roman dishes and pasta is always fresh. The flavor of their passata is the perfect base to create pasta amatriciana or a simple gnocchi al pomodoro. Last time we went, we had 2 specials: Ragu di Cinghiale and pasta nero di seppia. They were both delish and cannot wait to go back again.

Love love love! My taste buds love it! I doubt my waist appreciates what I put in it though (hahaha). The food here is so light and flavorful. It is rich in the sense of how luxurious the pastas are. I came in a group and while we did have a long wait the service when we did get it was amazing! They were all so friendly and helpful. I will definitely come back here for a date night or a way to treat my family to an amazing meal. The only dish I did not like was the pumpkin cheesecake (but I am also not a fan of cheesecake so that makes sense). Definitely this pasta is in my top tier list.
Oh Lupa, when I order a salad to be delivered, please, don't add a giant shiny fly to it- it doesn't contribute to my appetite.

What a lovely restaurant. The menu is quirky and hard to understand but the staff were on hand to explain and it actually helped make it a better experience. The food was lovely as were the drinks and the staff were super friendly and very attentive.

We went to Lupa's for my birthday based on a recommendation from a friend.  It was excellent!  Started with a great white wine recommended by the sommelier and it didn't break the bank.  Then the procciutto and mozzarella Excellent!  Our server Jim was attentive, friendly and did an awesome job.  Entrees were the cacio e Pepe and saltimbocca. With broccoli rape and potatoes on the side.  We left nothing on the plate.  Pasta was al dente and perfectly prepared.  Veal was equally delicious.  We ended with a olive oil cake.  The place is small with tables very close to each other so it gets a little noisy but we didn't mind.   Will go back for sure!
Ridiculously good food, service and also the wine list is superb. Nothing more to add.
Gross. Literally gross. Waiter was so pretentious and rude. The cacio e Pepe has butter in it. Why?! The gosh tasted so fishy and farm fed. Hated it. Will never go back
The most amazing charcuterie and bread! I would come and just get the focaccia as a snack. Very well known for the carbonara (with good reason!) Divine

Holy cow! Never seen a place fall so darn hard. Went 2 years ago and this place was great with great staff. Now this is 3rd or 4th rate staff, like really bad especially Ismael who appears to be disgruntled that he has to wait tables despite being a bar tender. Rude unhelpful and I thankful sums up ismael really well. The food matched the service. They are essentially serving slop pasta, had two pasta dishes and man were they so amateur it's not funny. It was sad being there Bc of how bad this place is right now, just don't go makes no sense so many better places.

Lovely service, good food. We had a pasta with short rib Ragu - good/heavy as expected. The pasta was well prepared. We split the fried cod main - it came with olives which were not specified on the menu. The cod itself was perfectly cooked. We also had the brussel sprout appetizer - well prepared but a bit sweet.

If you have read any of my reviews, you would know that I am a carb and Italian restaurant whore. It's true. There is practically no pasta that I won't devour. Came to Lupa to check out restaurant week's fixed menu and it did not disappoint. For about forty bucks (give or take) I had a three course meal. Started with a veggie crostini, than had a fettuccini followed by a pork dish. Because it was a special menu, the portions were smaller than normal. I saw many customers sitting nearby happily devouring large bowls of what appeared to be delicious pastas.  While service was very friendly, it was slow. The place was packed so it was understandable. Additionally, it felt like a long afternoon in Italy where you could eat, drink, and enjoy the company of friends at a leisurely pace. Would not recommend coming here on a first date or with someone who you don't enjoy spending time with for that reason.

Used to come here all the time during college. While the most recent time I came back was still good, and the staff was nice and friendly, the bucatini I got was a little over cooked and soft. Overall still a solid experience.

Good afternoon. I just dined at your restaurant Lupa. I have dined there many times through the years, but this experience was so thoroughly disgusting and upsetting I felt I needed to reach out. I was with my family for an early dinner when a dead bug fell from the ceiling onto our table in front of the waiter. She apologized and took the bug away. We then spent the rest of our dinner swatting away bugs from our plates. We ate inside and you have open doors. I know, some will come in, but this was beyond dirty and disgusting. Before we finished our meal a second bug fell from the gross ceiling, this one alive. The buss boy then killed it on our table leaving a blood stain next to my wife. I told the waitress and she proceeds to talk to the manager Gulio. We could not finish eating after that. It was nauseating. The manager never even came to our table to check on us. I paid my bill and left. I was so upset I went to the manager to thank him for not even coming over to check on my family and myself. He was so rude and condescending. He said sure, I'm sorry there are bugs. What do you want me to do. He was being a complete wise guy. I will never come back to any restaurant you own again Mr.Bastianich. You need to know that your restaurant is dirty, full of bugs and your manager is a disgrace. It would be beneficial for you to rectify this as soon as possible. I will also be reporting this to the board of health. You have some nerve judging other peoples food when yours is in such disarray.
Amazing food and amazing service. Definitely need a reservation in advance. The pasta is cooked to perfection

Ordered take out from Lupa a couple months ago and was a bit disappointed. I figured the in-person experience must be better considering all of the positive reviews. So I came here the other night on a date and oh my god. Talk about pouring salt in a wound. The food was even worse in person and was so salty that we didn't finish a single dish. The waitress, upon seeing my tightly puckered lips react to the ungodly amounts of sodium, asked me if anything was wrong. My mouth was so dry, I couldn't even respond before she walked away. If this place ever goes out of business, it will likely be due to ludicrous salt bills they must receive from their vendor on a weekly basis.
The bad reviews posted are in my experience misguided. I had a wonderful meal here.  Delicious dishes. I had the steak. Nicely prepared.  Great ambiance. We sat outdoors.

Disappointed.   I haven't been there since Mario Battali owned it. We ordered a bottle of wine and wanted to enjoy it while we ate a plate of prosciutto but the server kept interrupting and almost demanded that we order.  Finally we ordered three types is pasta. None of them were finished. I make better carbonara in my kitchen.  I won't go back

The food was good, the music was awesome, but unfortunately the service wasn't good. A few things: 1) sat us 15 minutes after reservation even though we all showed up on time 2) they forgot one of our appetizers, 3)asked if we wanted another bottle of wine and then forgot it, 4) ran out of cheese (how does an Italian restaurant run out of cheese), 5) took for ever to bring check and then grab check. Tbh I'm convinced our waiter was stoned, he looked confused a couple times. Again decent spot and if you have a good waiter probably a great spot
Delicious.  Cacio Pepe.  Duck. Lupa Tartufo.  Can't wait to eat here again!
waiting orders for hours. Burrata was not fresh at all. The bread can tell you this restaurant is far from good Italian food. Pasta was fine . Honestly, not good overall.
Food was delicious and the restaurant felt cozy! We had a good time and good food. We will definitely go back again.

Best pasta I've ever had. I'll be dreaming of the al dente heaven for years to come. We ordered the squid ink, clams and cacio e pepe pasta. All delicious. Wine offering good, if a little overpriced (more than the usual upcharge). The restaurant has a nice feel, intimate and cozy. One star off for service... generally good but a little pretentious and we had three different waiter when we were there which was strange.

Went here for my birthday dinner and had an incredible time! The atmosphere is dimly lit and cozy. The som was quite helpful in recommending a wine, which we loved and was exactly what we were looking for. The appetizers and entrees were flavorful and well portioned. We were so full by the end but still managed to save room for dessert. Highly recommend!

Unfortunately both me and my girlfriend had food poisoning within 2 hours of dining here. I suspect the water we were served was contaminated. Food was ok but definitely not as great as alternatives with lesser reputation. They recently switched a chef which might be the issue. Service was fine.
Lovely and delicious Roman food on quiet Greenwich Village street. Ismael and Kevin are wonderful bartenders and the food is top notch!
Great pasta, amazing location.  Sat at the bar and did some fun people watching on a busy Saturday.  Can't wait to come back
Been coming for 20 years - and all good things must come to an end. The food was basically inedible - so salty and off. Nothing tasted right. Last time old friend :(

I read the reviews and went anyway thinking that the salt issue was being over exaggerated. It's not. We had the Brussels sprouts and arancini to start, both were really delicious. Then came the pasta. Oh my, my rigatoni was not edible. Not only was it salty but it was way underdone (not al dente, it was basically raw). I hated to have to send it back but I had to. The new plate served was saltier than the last. In the end I didn't eat it. My fiancé had the bucatini, it was salty but edible and cooked Al dente. The service was lovely, our waitress was great. Maybe the chef has lost his sense of taste? I don't know. Id probably go back for the apps if I were in the area and needed a quick bite but I'd be weary of the pasta.

Hopping! We had reservations for a late seating on a rainy Saturday night and the place was filled. Service was quick and attentive. She started with a couple of delicious cocktails (An Italian Mule and Aperol Spritz. Both delicious, not too sweet. Can't say that about the Manhattan that followed, tho!)  it tasted like a liquid cough syrup. Waaay too heavy on the cherry syrup. The buratta and Baccala Salad were both strong.  Very flavor and perfect blend of flavors.  The cod is salted in house and was tender, large chunks and served cold.  Buratta was velvety and a perfect consistency for the matched peas toasted peppers and vegetables that accompanied it.  We had two pastas, the linguine with clam sauce and a black (squid ink) penne with seafood. Both were excellent but a bit on the salty side.  The pastas were very fresh and tasty, high quality.   The dishes are meant to be eaten w pieces of everything the chef puts inside because the flavors blend and support each other.  By the time our Branzini main and garlic-and-farro side arrived was totally stuffed. But the fish is filleted w the head and tail on laid on a bed of sauce and asparagus. It was tasty. The faro was lacking in flavor but again when blended w the fish it added texture and gained support, but could do without it.  Overall, good meal and great ambiance for a Saturday night out. Probably overpriced for the misses on some of the dishes. I think if I returned would go for bar for drinks and just try out their pastas.

Lupa was some of the best Italian food my girlfriend and I have had in a while! We both ordered Cacio e Pepe and it was delicious. The place we pretty busy but our waiter was very nice and the service overall was excellent. They also had an amazing selection of wines to choose from.
First trip to NYC since covid and wanted to do it right. Lupa was a great start with a top notch meal simple, great pasta. Covid precautions with some plastic barrieres also kept noise down!

I had lunch here last week (on a Friday). I got there just as they opened and there were not many people there.  By 1pm, they had a large crowd.  The food was excellent, the service friendly, but I'm docking them a star as it was very slow service.  Looking around, it seemed they forgot we were there as other tables seemed to be getting their food (and water refilled) before us.  We started with the Fritto Misto with Calimari and Artichokes, and then had the Spaghetti Carbonara and the Pollo alla Diavola, along with a side of the Snap Peas with Guanciale.   The only dish I was disappointed in was the Snap Peas. Everything else was wonderful.  They also had a nice selection of wines by the glass.

Disappointed.  Service was ok and the food was underwhelming.  Hummus crostini was unseasoned. Plain chick pea paste.  Focaccia was like cake and not very savory. The chicken liver crostino was too salty. Asparagus was good.  The crispy pork belly and pork chop special was bland and a little dry despite all the fat.  It should've been served with a sauce and some kind of garnish. Ordered the ricotta gnocchi which was supposed to be very good but there was barely any sausage noticeable in the purée and tasted like Ragu spaghetti sauce.  We decided to skip dessert there and walked over to Morgensteins for ice cream to end the evening on a sweet note.  I was so excited to try Lupa because their Instagram looks great but I would not recommend it.

I booked this place for my Valentine's Day dinner, prefixed menu of course. The four course meal was lovely and we sat next to another couple, appropriate social distance precautions taken of course; they told us they are regulars and have been over a several amount of years and they have never had more exquisite Italian food in new  York quite like this place. It made me feel good about my choice. It was freezing though despite there being outside heaters. The food was perfection. No issues and they were very attentive to mine and my significant others needs at all times. They were very professional and lovely atmosphere. I hope to experience when social regulations are normal again.

Lupa was a highlight of my trip to NY. The food was amazing, priced well, and of high quality. But more importantly, the staff made my visit incredible. The waiter was friendly and we were able to talk to the chef from Italy. The desert at the end was very special: tiramisu in a bialetti espresso machine.

We had an excellent dinner here last weekend. Beatrice was so accommodating and reserved the "sidewalk" table for us, which is normally first come first serve. The waiter Diego was very nice and attentive. The food was really good! We had a craving for carbonara and cacio e pepe and both dishes didn't disappoint. Perfectly al dente and flavorful. They know what they're doing: I felt like I was back in Rome! It's a bit pricey but not more than others in the area. Definitely recommended.
Really yummy food! Not quite as noteworthy as Maialino, but a great lavish Roman dinner all the same!

I came here today for lunch and very excited to get the food. The service was great but the only thing I felt weird "they served pork chop with a medium" that's totally wrong! If your bad luck you can get some parasites and can die to eat raw pork! I don't want to hear something bad happen with anyone and hope they will fix it.

This place is overrated. Pasta tasted like chef boyardee. Garbage. I was craving cheese and saw carbonara was popular choice on yelp. I didn't really want to come all this way just for a carbonara, but when I told the waitress I wanted something with cheese she enthusiastically suggested it. But it just tasted like too much pepper and the noodles were undercooked for my tastes, harder than al dente. I tried my friends pastas and one tasted too salty. It was just bad. I wouldn't recommend.

Many thanks to yelp for advising Lupa. It's in a perfect location and we were definitely pleased with our experience. All of the food items are excellent, their menu is amazing, I really like their Olive Oil Cake with Mixed Berry Confettura & Sesame Gelato. Service was good and everyone working here was really nice and hospitable. I would definitely drop in again.

Service has really gone south here ! Our first experience two years ago was just top notch so many be my expectations were different. I guess it's the post covid ramp up issues most of the restaurants are facing but the service staff was just sub par in terms of general greeting , cleaning the table , food presentation , taking the order , checking on us , we had to call the wait staff for a refill of our sparkling water and also to light the candle on the table lol... i won't be going back here ..

I'd give it a 4.5 tbh. Amazing service from friendly staffs that are willing to answer any question to professional staffs that know what they are doing. The know their wine and pair it really well. Another staff cleaned off the crumbs from the table and was very attentive and polite. Another staff was so attentive that after a few dishes he realized that my mom and I are sharing everything so the when we ordered the second round, he automatically asked the kitchen to separate one order to two different plates for us even though we didn't ask. The cocktails were good, not watered down and Toltec Money Tree is a pretty unique cocktail that's really awesome. Their meat and seafood dishes (appetizers and entree) are all very tasty but they are the best when it comes to their pastas. You will absolutely regret it I'd you don't order them. The bread is really soft and nice too, and the olive oil is fresh. The coffee is good and dessert was just perfect. I'd definitely go back again and highly recommend this place! I'm also definitely bringing my entire family here when they visit me next time. Nice atmosphere and some noise but not loud. Pretty relaxing and cute interior. Restroom is at the back and decently clean, the only thing is that the lights are so dim I could barely see. I had to turn my phone's flashlight on to retouch my makeup after. Walkable to a couple different subway stations and not hard to find. I do suggest people to make reservations though, as they do get busy. I also love the Capitoline Wolf as their logo and the mini sculptures as their decorations. Reminded me of my trips to Italy and I've always loved the sculpture and story

Food was just ok. What a terrible experience overall. Our waiter literally quarreled with our busboy which ruined the entire mood and vibe of the dinner. No one apologized. We spoke to the manager and she could care less. Very unpleasant evening.
The food is very good though unspectacular. The service was horrible. Both the host and server were indifferent and borderline rude. Not a relaxing or enjoyable experience.

New chef- DONT GO HERE!! Apparently the talent has left the building. They had a new chef for the last few weeks and all he does is put red pepper over a bunch of recipes he obviously does not know how to make!! Biggest disappoint!!

This place is overstretched. The food might be good but nothing exceptional. More problematically, they make you wait way too long for it. After 45 minutes of waiting I had to ask to take it to go, and it took another 20 minutes. All tables around me were having the same problem.

Do I ever know what the menu says? No. Is that going to stop me from ordering? NOPE! Lupa is undeniably one of the best Roman/Italian restaurants on the lower west side of NYC. I love the ambiance of Lupa while sipping wine and enjoying my meal. The pasta is as fresh as can be, not overcooked, perfectly al dente.

Came here for a family members birthday and it was delicious and the service was great! It was the 5 of us and we started out with 2 orders of burrata, 2 orders or fritta misto, and large portion of grilled octopus. For entrees we had the carbonara, gnocchi, pasta with clams, and ox tail. Everything was delicious and on point. We ended the dinner with the ricotta cheesecake and it was superb. I recommend this restaurant anyone in the city. FYI the portions are small so make sure you order extra.

One of my favorite Italian restaurants in the city. Took my boyfriend here for his birthday and we couldn't have asked for a better birthday experience. The sommelier bestowed us with knowledge like he hopped straight off the plane from France. The olives tasted like they came straight from the vines. Could have had more crushed red pep. 10/10 would bring my boyfriend back for his next birthday if he still deserves it.

Excellent service, and their crispy duck is fantastic! Was a little bit disappointed with octopus - it wasn't tough but it also wasn't tender. For $30 you expect something a bit better. Portions are generous, which was nice in case of the duck. Excellent side with mushroom orzo - it was delicious and very filling. We also got frito misto with calmari and artichokes, and unfortunately artichokes weren't very "meaty" and consisted mostly of deep-fried leaves. For desert we got Lupa Tartufo, which was more frozen than it should have been, so it was hard to eat.  Overall, it was a pleasant meal and I strongly recommend getting the side with mushrooms and the crispy duck. But it was a special occasion and you expect everything to be perfect when you leave over $200, and unfortunately it wasn't.

The gnocchi. Get some and eat it slowly while you smile stupidly because it is that good. If you're eating pasta, get one of the pastas made in house. I like the sauce to the spaghetti carbonara, but would have liked it more in house made pasta. My husband got the bucatini and loved it. I'm going to stick to the gnocchi because it alone deserves five stars.
Although tasty, food was cold. Several items on the menu were unavailable. Service was lacking. I would give this restaurant a pass.

Came here for our anniversary, the goat cheese agnolotti was very good. I told my hubs to order the infamous cacio pepe but he ordered something else by accident which he ate anyway, then we ended up ordering and sharing the cacio. To peppery for me but I'd definitely love to come back one day and try the carbonara which looks good from pictures. It was also perfectly al dente btw, my hubs loved it and called it his favorite meal. I can't even remember the first thing he ate but it was in a meat sauce I think. I also liked the look of the place. Cool bathrooms too.

We waited an hour to be waited on, and never had an actual server. No customer service, and was talked down to when we ordered. The food was good, but the service was awful. It was so hot all meal too

A beautiful NYC Italian restaurant experience even during Covid! I felt safe and the staff were so friendly! Not to mention the clam linguine and the rabbit ragu rigatoni were both outstanding! We also got the spinach and hot bacon salad which was honestly one of the best I've had. Definitely recommend

Good food, horrible service and place unfortunately. Had to wait forever even though i had reservations. Also I was surprised how cold it was inside, it's like no heating at all and I couldn't focus on my delicious food.

Hands down my favorite pasta place.  My boyfriend is big on pasta and thus we have tried many pasta places in the city such as Marea, Carbone and Lilia.  The most memorable pasta constantly making me want to go back for is Bucatini from Lupa.  My boyfriend's favorite pasta dish is Fusili from Marea. However for the price, Lupa seems to be a better choice.

Absolutely delicious Italian food and the wine was divine. Make sure to get the crispy cod, and of course...the pasta! For such a top notch restaurant, you'd think the service might be a bit better -- but that's a small gripe. Definitely get a reservation for dinner if you can!

Wanted a nice Roman restaurant to celebrate my moms birthday this past weekend, and thought that Lupa fit the bill. They have an amazing, extensive wine list. You start with fresh rosemary bread, as well as crostini with fava bean spread (my favorite). We ordered the crispy squash blossoms, they were phenomenal. My dad got the crispy cod; the tomato wasn't as spicy as the menu described, but it didn't have to be- the dish was delicious. My mom got the Bolognese special of the night and thought it was yummy. I went for the classic Cacio e Pepe- I thought it was very good, but be warned if you're not great with pepper, there's definitely a good amount of it in this dish. The only thing that wasn't our favorite was the side of corn risotto (I don't recall the exact name). It was pretty good, but just seemed to be lacking some spice of some sort. Overall, a delicious restaurant- we'll be back!
I've been going here for years and it's one of my favs. The food is always great and I love that they reserve half the seats for walk-ins. Great cozy and friendly energy.

Lupa is a little jewel of an Italian restaurant here in NYC. Here you'll find authentic Italian cooking with a menu that you'll be asking the waiter to explain to you but don't be intimidated. This is good, simple, wholesome cooking that will warm your belly and your heart. This review, however, is not about the food. It's about the service. Too often customers use Yelp as a weapon. They bitch about the food, the service, or both. My friends and I had reservations at 5pm on December  26th, the day after Christmas. Niceties aside, no one wants to work the day after Christmas but in the hospitality industry most people have to. It's gut wrenching for workers but ignored by entitled people the world over. That's why when we sat at our table (as always but especially at this time) I made it a point to be friendly and genuinely grateful for the privilege before us. Our server, Michael, a comedian from L.A., was friendly and knowledgeable. His service was flawless. So was the wine recommendation from David the sommelier who steered us towards a cab blend from the Lozzo region of Italy. It was delicious. In short, be kind, respectful, and leave your server a big tip. Seriously. Living is hard and rent is unaffordable for those in the hospitality industry. Covid has only made things worse. Thank you, Michael. Thank you, David, and thanks to everyone at Lupa for making our night special.

If swimming in the Dead Sea with your mouth open is your idea of a good time, this is the place for you! The food had salt on the salt on top of the salt. Think Salt Bae with a twitch. Waiter was good hence the two stars. If you plan on coming here make sure you hydrate adequately every day for a few months in advance.

They were experimenting with the seating arrangements the night we went which ended up with us not being seated right away for our reservation. The staff could not have made our wait and subsequent dining experience more pleasant. They were upfront, honest, and genuine, and the drinks while we waited and prosciutto at the table didn't hurt. Everything that touched our table that night was outstanding from the heirloom tomato salad to the cacio e Pepe and agnolotti. We will be back

If I could give 10 stars I would. Everything was phenomenal - food, wine, service, and ambiance. We did the vegetarian pasta tasting menu (no substitutions allowed as we don't eat beef or pork) along with the wine pairing. The food absolutely delicious- it was clean, bold, authentic, rustic, and flavorful. The staff was very attentive and explained the food/wine. It was very busy but all the dishes were timed correctly. My favorite dishes was the squash mezzelune and cacio e pepe. We ended off with a light pear sorbet which was absolutely delicious. I definitely plan to return to try the other dishes. We saw other dishes around us which looked amazing.

We came here during restaurant week but ended up ordering off the regular menu instead. They gave an amouse bouche to start, I believe a chickpea based bite. And we got the cacio e pepe and beef ragu. Both were great- simple and flavorful.

Hangs down one of the best restaurants I've ever eaten at. The staff was great and the food was amazing...their braised pork shoulder special was out of this world. If you're looking for an amazing app, the prosciutto with mozzarella was insanely delicious. They had a wonderful wine list and the atmosphere was incredible!

What a friendly service and fantastic food! These guys do know how to cook a great pasta. Their amatriciana and alla gricia are mind-blowing and NY strip steak is something I never had in other places.

Lupa used to be one of our go to restaurants. We got delivery from there two weeks ago and were so disappointed. Maybe the pandemic has taken a toll on the kitchen. We ordered chicken liver crostini - bland and soggy, escarole salad - not bad but $19?  Short rib strozapretti - okay if it weren't from a high end Italian restaurant, broccoli rabe - bland, could have used some red pepper flakes or something and Eggplant and summer squash - really terrible with a weird sweetness to it.  No bread came with this order. No joke intended - and the portions were so small. With tax, tip and delivery fee the bill was $119.  Clearly not worth it. They got two stars because the order came promptly and was packed nicely. The food clearly wasn't the fault of the delivery service. I'm really sad that Lupa has gone downhill, it used to be so good.

I was really excited to try Lupa on my recent visit to NY City.  I was in town visiting a friend and he had made reservations.  We decided to try their "Pasta Sampler" of four different home made pastas and sauces.  Of course they up sold us on the 4 course wine pairing that went with the pasta sampling.  I was EXCITED!  Unfortunately, my expectations were way to high.  While the pastas were very good (texture and flavor ) two of the sauces were supper strong and overbearing and even a little bitter.  That must have been the sauce with "Organ" meat.  Yup, that's right, organ meat. They would not tell us which organs and from "who" or what so we stopped asking.  After all, it's NY City. Two of the wines were very good and a good match. However two of the reds were not nearly strong or bold enough to stand up to the strong and "organie" meat sauce.  The wines flavors were lost.   On a bright note, our server was fantastic. Mave was her name I belief and she did a great job. Even took it in stride when we told her our disappoint with the final two wine parings.  Sadly, they're are so many good restaurants in NY City that it's hard to ever go back to something that was just "ok"
Good food and ambiance, but... the somm knowingly (having tasted it) served our table a bottle of corked wine, not knowing there were wine professionals at the table. Not cool.
Great Roman Italian style place. Service was good and food was a hit for me. I see myself coming back again here.

I rarely give a bad review.  Generally I read reviews before I go, and tend to be very happy with our choices.  Lupa was  real disappointment since we were very much looking forward to dinner there.  Our reservation wasn't ready when we arrived.  I realize that can happen and we had no issue waiting for a few minutes while a table was set-up.  20 minutes later after watching them seat several parties in front of us it was obvious there was no table being setup.  We actually had to wait for a party right by the door to leave.  Eventually that happened, it was cleared and we were sat.  Not a great location being by the door, and was very hot.  The hostess couldn't care less about the wait nor the lack of information as we crammed into the corner waiting for a table.  Then, 20 more minutes sitting at our table.  No greeting.  No water.  People walked by the table repeatedly - nobody acknowledged we were there.  No offer to take a drink order or even fill a water glass.  50 minutes after arriving we decided it was time to leave.  Quick chat with the manager but it was obvious they were plenty busy and whether we stayed or not was of little interest.  Thankfully the area is abundant with restaurants, found another place within minutes, were sat and they seemed genuinely happy we were there.  Do I think Lupa will care?  Nope.  They have plenty of demand...for now.

What a great dining experience! My sister and I stumbled upon this place accidently and I'm so glad we did! We were treated like family and the food was amazing. Wish I lived in NYC; I'd come all the time.

Restaurant over booked and never get to seat customers with reservations after a very long wait.  Offered no apology for their mismanagement.  Host and manager need better training as they couldn't careless about customers with a reservation who waited for a very long time.  Very disappointed and I would not recommend this place to anyone looking to have a nice time.
We went in a group of 5 and ordered their tasting menu. Food was good and classic. Love their pastas. It was very quiet in a Saturday afternoon. Love the decor and atmosphere.

An intimate restaurant. The wine selection is unbelievable and the small dishes and starters are superb. Some of the best pasta I've eaten. If you go the Apricot Roccota Cheesecake is a must have. It'll be gone in 30 seconds whether you are full or not. Oh and Joe Bastinich likes to make an appearance once in a while.

Been a while since we were here, seated outside which was fine. Attentive, helpful service. The best prosciutto I've ever had, plus other excellent appetizers. However, saltimbocca was incredibly disappointing, so tough the serrated steak knife was incapable of sawing through parts of it. The term "shoe leather" is appropriate. I was with a group and not in a contentious mood, so aside from a comment to the waiter let it pass. The uneven quality is certainly not what it was when Mario was running it.

Came here expecting great food and unfortunately was very disappointed. Food was overpriced and bland. I ordered the octopus appetizer and it was severely over cooked and difficult to chew. I also ordered a whole fried fish which didn't even come to me as a whole fish but a chopped up small portion. The fish itself had bones everywhere and was not properly descaled, I was spitting out bones and scales almost every bite. I am a huge cacio e Pepe lover but this dish extremely bland I had to ask for extra salt and pepper to try to make it taste decent. Other than the food it took about two hours to get fed. Was hoping to like this place but would definitely not return.

I can't say enough great things about this place. I honestly don't know why it only has 4 stars on here because it is fantastic. My friend and I started out with a couple of drinks. The drinks were reasonably priced for this area (it is more expensive than what we would typically see at home in, but we weren't surprised by this) . They brought out some warm bread and oils to start with and it was out of this world. I had two baskets. For entrees, we got the perfect Negron. I'm practically drooling just thinking about the food haha it was so good. I had no doubt the crispy cod, but I'm fairly picky with fish sometimes. However, it was cooked perfectly and was served on a bed of tomato sauce and sweet, grilled chipollini onions. Would highly recommend!

I once read in an magazine interview Julia Roberts said this is her favorite place to grab a bowl of pasta, so naturally I had to come and check out Lupa. I saw that they had a tasting menu and of course, the idea of having bowl after bowl of pasta is appealing to just about everyone, and I didn't know how to choose just one to sum up a restaurant's experience! The pasta at Lupa is super tasty, and any dish with the guanciale is TO DIE FOR. It is probably the best tasting bacon-esque thing that I have ever eaten. Insider tip, if you get the tasting menu, you can take leftovers of each home in small boxes. It's a LOT of just straight up pasta and sauce. There's not much meat, vegetables, or any other mix ins, so get ready for a lot of carbs.

Absolute horrible service and food was nothing special. The meats board WITHOUT the cheese is $38 dollars. Willing to spend $ for good food, but this was very sub par. Pasta is soaked in oil and flavors are weak. We waited 45 minutes before ordering and it took another 45 for the check - had to speak to manager. Don't recommend.

Upscale italian flare. The spaghetti carbonara is the best we've ever had and could give Italy a real competition, with perfectly creamy sauce and well-rendered pancetta. Portion is good for good for one person. I had the fish of the day with a sweet caramelized onion, rutabega I've tried the first time, and some fine sauce I can't put into a culinary. It's pricey for me but a matches the gastronomic value. Love this place.
Great food, great drinks, awesome staff. Their chicken and pasta amatriciana are top notch. Get here if ever in the city i guarantee it won't disappoint

PLACE WAS GREAT!!!!! Started with the burrata, split the carbonara w/ pepper and branzino. General manager is awesome. Can't say enough good things about that guy! Truly made the entire experience top notch.. looking forward to the next visit!!!!

Went there for a dinner with my wife for my birthday. Staff was excellent food was excellent and they even gave us a dessert for my birthday. I strongly recommend this place it does get busy real quick and is a little loud but overall a must if you are by NYU

My friend and I came here over the holidays to catch up, and were lucky enough to snag a reservation. I would highly recommend making a reservation as they get extremely busy. The space is very cozy and intimate, with a nice bar in the front and tables in the front and back of the restaurant. Our waiter was very nice and the food was very good. We both got pasta dishes and they were delicious. I would definitely recommend coming here for a date or catching up with a friend.

Came here recently for dinner and it was a great night! The food and cocktails were delicious! It felt like an authentic Italian expereince. The outdoor heaters kept us warm enough to be comfortable sitting outside in the middle of January.
Excellent spot for a New York dinner . The food was amazing . The service and staff were very friendly. This is definitely a must stop for dinner

Where do I start, we came in  hungry looking for something delicious to eat and we received amazing! We had seared scallops over this finger licking good tomato base sauce that had veggies in it, omg so good. I also had linguine with cheese and garlic, I wish my paste was giving 3 more minutes of cooking time but it was still good. My husband had branzino  fish that was coupled with this mint pesto sauce spinach and spaghetti with garlic and olive oil. This place left us fully satisfied. Oh and we also enjoy a piece olive oil cake with ice cream and preaches it wasn't amazing but good. I will definitely go back. They had basic style utensils, beautiful big bowl and plates and a very neat restroom.

Amazing Roman comfort food at an affordable price- better than what I had in Rome! The marinated olives appetizer gets overlooked but highly recommend.  The bucatini dish is a MUST try!!! Their focaccia bread and olive oil is soo good. Just go!! Gets packed on the weekend so make a reservation!
The Pork porterhouse they serve for restaurant week is outstanding. I highly recommend that. Look Forward to trying other stuff from here in the future.
Cacio e Pepe is definitely  worth going to Lupa for.  Also really enjoyed the Vespa rosso.
Amazing ricotta gnocchi and side of mushrooms. Loved the cheesecake. Very filling and satisfying.

Very warm atmosphere, great for a date night. My boyfriend and I had went to celebrate his birthday. The staff was very sweet and attentive. The waiter helped us choose a wine. They offer complimentary crostinis. I had gotten the octopus dish, I had been eyeing that since I explored the menu. It was delicious! Tender and perfectly charred.  My boyfriend got the the special, squid ink pasta. And we finished the night with the ricotta cheesecake. Agreat meal.

My wife and I had a fantastic meal at Lupa last night.  Alex was our server and he was very kind and attentive, listening to my wife's food allergies and making sure our choices were safe.  Such a great neighborhood spot with food to die for.  Recommended!

Totally not the restaurant it used to be. We used to come regularly... since then, we've moved to LA and come when we visit. The food has taken a nose dive. B- at best. The truffle pasta at $49 looks like ramen swimming in milk with a ton of totally bland truffle grated on top (had no idea shaved Black Truffles could taste like nothing).  Go to Marea for excellent Italian. Don't waste your time.
Expect a meal well worth the wait. One of the few places I go in the city to eat Cacio E Pepe. Cacio E Pepe is a Roman dish and is very delicious.

Went last Saturday night with friends for dinner. What a great place. It's not a big place but it's very nice and service was great! The food was terrific and all 4 of us loved our plates which consisted of homemade pasta , pate, octopus ,steak etc.. wine list was excellent and desserts were yummy too! Def recommend this place .

Ordered valentines dinner well in advance, showed up in person all the way from across town and they said "sir we've been meaning to contact you, we don't have your food and are all committed for the night, so sorry."  I also called several hours in advance to modify the order and they never called back. I was so pissed that I didn't even want the food anymore because I had no faith that they could even put together a decent meal with this utter, gross mismanagement.

Food here is wayyyy too delicious. By the time I finished the food, I sadly realized I didn't take any pictures. Bummer. But all I could say is definitely try everything, especially the ragú. Very delicious. Definitely worth coming back!!

Great food. I went here with some friend from out of town and I had the spaghetti carbonara and it was amazing. The pieces of pancetta definitely made the dish and balacalito salad was so freaking good. The bartender did a great job on the drinks, all i needed was one for the night. I would definitely go here again especially with friends or go on a date. Our server was really great also.

I always love coming here for the pasta. We had the escarole salad and brussel sprouts to start then shared the cavatelli with sausage and pesto and then the short rib pasta- they were delicious. The sauces were seasoned perfectly and the service was great! We love coming here on a Sunday afternoon for a late lunch/early dinner.

Wasn't sure I'd be satisfied with just a pasta dish, even though their pastas are highly rated, so I opted for a meat option and got the cornish hen (which was on the menu in Italian). It was perfectly cooked and moist, with delicious crispy skin, in a great sauce, over a bed of fancy mushrooms. It was also a pretty generous portion for a chicken entree. The house bread was very good, which is always a huge bonus and they brought out seconds. The service was very attentive and my server explained options on the menu thoroughly. They also brought out a complimentary crostini that was good, although I am not sure what was on it (hummus or almond paste, maybe). My only minor complaint is that the food took a little too long to prepare. Overall, an excellent meal (at a reasonable price point-$26-for this quality)!

A must if you are in NY ! The BEST Cacio e Pepe pasta I have ever had, cooked perfectly al dente ! My husband had the Sirloin Steak which was to die for! We loved it so much we got to go the next day. We can't wait to return!!

Lupa is good, but for me it is not as over-the-top spectacular as some reviews make it out to be.  To begin with, while Negroni on tap is an interesting novelty, I don't know that it results in a superior or even standard Negroni - and, I sort of resent paying $13 for a cocktail that is poured from a tap without the bartender having to do much at all.  As for the food, as is often the case, the appetizer was better - buffalo mozzarella with marinated eggplant was nicely balanced and tasty.  The pasta dishes were good but not great - maybe not as al dente as I'd like, and too salty.  Very salty.  Ambience is nice, but not as if I have been transported to Rome.  If the prices were 30% lower this would be a solid neighborhood Roman style Italian place.
The one and only place in Manhattan where pasta takes just like in Rome. The chicken diavola is one of my favorite dishes. Excellent wine selection and service.
Really good place for dates and to catch up with friends. Took my boyfriend on his birthday, the waiters are really friendly and they give really good suggestions. Will definitely go again!

First time I discovered this place I'd just spent two weeks in Italy and stumbled onto this place while walking w/ some friends from out of town. Since then, this place has become my favorite Italian place (and held it for over 15 yrs). One of the few spots that does both pasta and meats extremely well. Would choose this spot over hotter places in town like Carbone, Marea and L'Artusi in a heartbeat.

Probably one of my new favorite authentic Italian restaurants. I had the bucatini which was AMAZING. The food was so flavorful and made to satisfy and not make you feel disgustingly full. Everything tasted great down to the foccacia bread they serve complimentary.
The pasta tasting menu is a steal.  All of the pasta tastes extremely fresh and the quality of the service is great!
Excellent place love  the ambiance and service. A good place for family events or romantic evening out with that special person.
Excellent food as always, friendly eager staff and excellent service make this still one of my favorite Italian eateries in nyc

Delicious, high quality and authentic! I would recommend this place to anyone seeking a spectacular Italian dining experience in NYC. The service is top notch where the staff appreciates their guests.

We had the Roman tasting menu which was cool to try but worth the $60 a head we paid. This place apparently has quite the reputation and I can see why. Really 'cool' place with a great vibe and lovely surroundings/atmosphere. Food was really solid and drinks were good. High quality experience
We had really good experience with Lupa. The spaghetti carbonara was amazing. We sat at the bar, the bartender recommended the wine to pair with our dishes and she did very good job.

WARNING: KEEP YOUR RECEIPTS. I went with my friend on a Tuesday afternoon around 4pm to get a couple drinks before heading across the street for dinner. The waiter outside was very kind to us and told us to head right to the bar. That's where our experience went SOUTH. The bartender didn't bother to look our way even though he saw us walk in (we made eye contact). The bar and restaurant were pretty much empty with only a couple at the bar that was almost finished with their meal and drinks. We had to ASK for drinks without him asking us what we wanted. We then asked for a menu; which was an ordeal in its own. After it was all said and done he wasn't friendly nor did he care for our business even though we were nothing but nice to him. HERE'S the kicker: I always save my receipts with what I tip. We gave him $5 for pouring 4 glasses of wine.... Which is COMPLETELY reasonable. Well, my credit card statement came out a day ago and it said he added FOUR EXTRA DOLLARS on top of my already $5 tip. The most concerning part of this all is imagine how much money he has weaseled out of people who don't bother to save their receipts. Will NOT be returning.

A popular West Village destination for obvious reasons. Good food. Good Wine. An impressive 'by the bottle' wine list. Very nice selection of salumi. Hard to find a better dressed salad. But if f they're packed and you're in line for say 20 minutes, they'll still try their damnedest to get you out as fast as they can and they're not being very coy about it. Unbecoming for a high ranking establishment like this.

Went to Lupa with 4 friends to celebrate a birthday. We were expecting an amazing experience as we had heard so many great things. The food was average. I ordered the saltimbocca- it was plated so poorly. No color at all. Just a brown patty on my plate. Would not go back and would not recommend.

We went to this restaurant based on the recommendation of Rachel Ray for the pasta. We had the casserecce with short rib meat sauce and papardelle with chantrelles. The pasta was tasty and cooked well. You could tell the pasta was fresh. The short rib meat was a little tough/dry which was disappointing as I'm used to short rib meat in a sauce falling apart. I had to cut the meat pieces with a knife. Overall the flavors were good but nothing stood out to bring value to the cost. This was the most costly meal we've had in NY but the food was not the best. Also, Lupa by far has to be the most over priced wine list in the country! They are selling $19 bottles of wine for $100!!! I get restaurants mark up alcohol greatly but I've never been ripped off like that.
I absolutely love Lupa - the food is excellent, the service is great and you can always get a spot without a reservation - much more low key than Baboo (which is my favorite) but a solid option!

Fuck this place. Made a reservation a month in advance to celebrate my wife's birthday. Ordered a special birthday dessert in advance, so they knew it was a special occasion. Had us waiting 30 minutes with no end in sight and  my 92 year old mother getting pushed around waiting for our table. Staff was rude and obnoxious. Left and went to Capriati Never coming back!
Wonderful restaurant. Quaint and elegant, delicious food, prompt service, and lots of warmth and kindness from the staff.
Delicious pasta(black spaghetti) I love it and so satisfying. Will definitely go back and order again.
Great Italian food.  Had cacio pepe spaghetti.  I think it needed more cheese.  Tasted a little plain.  The liver toast was good.

I read about Lupa in a Bib Gourmand list. We got to the place during a busy Tuesday lunch hour and still managed to get a seat. The people who run the place are very nice and friendly. The food cannot get better than that. We got complimentary bread and oil, and another appetizer which was delicious. The sphagetti pomodoro is probably one of the best I have tasted in NY. The price was definitely a little on higher side, but it was totally worth it! Cant wait to go and try the pasta tasting menu.

New favorite Italian restaurant. Amazing service, perfect table in the sunshine & excellent food at a decent price. The Casarecce short rib pasta was perfection and the Pesce al Cartoccio will lead me right back to this same spot very soon. I know this restaurant has been around for some time and I'm just glad I finally tried it. That's what summer is for.

I really wanted to be a fan of this place but was very disappointed. Showed up on a Saturday night and we were seated right away. We were served bread, which was delicious, and also ordered wine. They serve wine by the quartino here which is great if you don't want to order a bottle but want a little bit more than a glass. For the entree, I ordered the cacio e pepe, which is seemingly a very simple dish. I couldn't even eat this dish as it was unbearably salty/peppery. Our waiter never came back to check on us after being served so didn't even have the option of sending it back. My friend also tried some of mine and couldn't even finish his bite. The ambience was nice and I really wanted to like this place, but frankly I can't trust a restaurant that screws up cacio e pepe that badly.

A great surprise on a rainy day. We got our reservations here quickly without a hassle, something I truly appreciate in this city. This Roman style restaurant is an ideal choice for a romantic dinner. A venue with great food and wine.

The food and atmosphere was amazing. My only reason for four stars, and maybe I shouldn't hold this against the restaurant, was a random person off the street coming in and started talking and hitting on my friend. It was really weird. Lol

Dined here with a good friend after attending The Accomplice. The sommelier was 100% on point with his recommendation and the plates we shared were exquisite. Don't be afraid to try and share, the accommodate nicely. Highly suggest for a special night out of to celebrate friendship.

Wasn't blown away by Lupa. Some dishes were really good while others lacked - for the good: the burrata app was lovely as was were the gnocchi (even though the portion was a tad small). The cappellacci with smoked lemon ricotta was just ok - the corn was a little strange and again the portion was on the smaller side. I enjoyed my cocktail but my date's tasted like straight coke. Atmosphere was a little strange, there was no music playing and was very hot inside on a summer night
Sooo good that I came back the next day for more.  The cacio e pepe & l'amatriciana are my favorites.  My new favorite nyc resto.

I am always hesitant to go back to a restaurant where I had such an outstanding meal because often it doesn't live up to my memories.  Well Lupa proved me wrong. Amazing meal the second time. Again had the marinated sardines which makes me want to replicate this at home. Spinach salad one of the best. Homemade pasta with black truffles. Broccoli rabe the best I've ever had. What a meal. Only thing lacking was the weak focaccia but who wants to fill up on bread.

We generally spend at least a weekend a month in the city (and hope to retire there), so Friday night we were thinking "cacio e pepe", and made a reservation at the No 1 ranking on Grubstreet, but were called a few days in advance to find they were closed that night, so the next one on the list that took reservations was Lupa. Had to wait a bit even though we had a reservation, and froze our asses off the entire meal, as the front door had to be open so servers could easily access those diners freezing outside. The first course, and best, was the bread offering- 2 pieces of crostini with a hummus-like spread and 3 pieces of melt in your mouth focaccia. Octopus was next, undercooked, and a very skimpy portion. Then came the cacio e pepe, which was undercooked as well. I'm not talking "al dente", I'm talking undercooked. The sauce was delicious though. We wanted short ribs next, but they were out, so we had lamb chops, which were easily one of the saltiest things we ever ate. After that, we bailed on dessert and coffee.
We love Lupa!! The pasta is amazing. If you can go on a Tuesday, the duck is outrageously good. Go!

A lovely white linen tablecloth Italian restaurant with attentive servers and an adventurous menu. I love the fact that the "definitions" of the food are on the back of the menu (thank you!).
